channel.title: Bypassing Update Server
channel.description: I have the new 440 client deob version of runescape. I (think) I made it connect to localhost, but I still need to get past the update server. Is there anyway I could make it ignore the connecting to update server so I can hopefully login with an username and password and connect to localhost?

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

O, I forgot that I downloaded the deobfuscated client from someone else’s sig. Your deobfuscater works until it gets past parsing the class files part and then it says like “find” invalid program or batch file 100’s of times then exits out of the batch file.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @popcorn89 popcorn89
item.description:
@popcorn89 wrote:

The only thing I ever posted was the deobfuscator, which still works…

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

I did lol, I meant when I want a brand new client deobfuscated with new updates whenever I want. Popcorn only posted 440, but it is no longer fully updated.

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

Alright thanks a lot man, one more thing… how do people deobfuscate the runescape client? I would like to be able to update my runescape client with the new java from jagex, but the variables are all screwed up.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

new java.net.Socket(IP,port); getOutputStream(); getInputStream();

If you mean interweb connextshun thats all you need to know basically . . .

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

I’ve been doing that to lots of different files including mopar’s jar and runescape’s jar. I am just trying to figure out how they are set up and how they implement things.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

If you have the jdk, do jar -xf src.zip

Then look at those files you’ll find out all kinds of crazy shit

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

What are some sources I can learn from? I have tried Sun Java Tutorials, but I don’t really know what to learn first. Is there a java tutorial for things you would actually use in a private server and how to implement them?

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

dont learn from private servers, they teach you how to be a moron.

especially if you want to make a new server

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

That’s where I started out at, but then there were too many newbies that didn’t know a single thing about anything at all and kept asking retarded questions. Moparscape.org/smf has been taken over by them, no intelligent discussions are taking place there.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

wrolyat:

Lol, yea I know how to do that =D. Thanks though, I just don’t understand how jagex has set up their files and all. It’s hard to decipher considering everything is a variable just about.

If I were you, I’d learn Java from Private Servers, which, believe it or not, is how I started learning Java…

psst private servers -> moparisthebest.com/smf

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:19, topic:35104”]No, learning is good. Except that Jagex is trying their best to keep their client hard to ‘learn’.

So you should probably start with something simpler.[/quote]

Such as HelloWorld.java

public class HelloWorld {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Hello World!");
    }
}

Hope that helps!

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

[quote=“pplsuqbawlz, post:13, topic:35104”]Wrong, that’s not the update server routines.

Disable that and none of the game will work. But congratulations you found DataLink! And there you have the routine for managing DataHandler.class… Now if only you had a brain.[/quote]

… That was not a constructive comment. I SUCK AT JAVA, I just started learning it. I am not an expert like you so do not treat me as though I should be at your level.

I’ll just freakin quit trying to learn it, no use if I just get shot down.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

You really are better off rewriting the server from the ground up. Good luck.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

You may as well make your own update server, it’d make distribution of the client much easier (which is why Jagex has implemented it :P).

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Bypassing the update server isn’t going to get you anywhere on having the new client connect to old servers written for 317, not without entirely rewriting the server anyway. Just so you know

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Wrong, that’s not the update server routines.

Disable that and none of the game will work. But congratulations you found DataLink! And there you have the routine for managing DataHandler.class… Now if only you had a brain.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @wrolyat wrolyat
item.description:
@wrolyat wrote:

public void run() { for (;;) { Class57 class57; synchronized (this) { for (;;) { if (aBoolean175) return; if (aClass57_174 != null) { class57 = aClass57_174; aClass57_174 = aClass57_174.aClass57_1352; if (aClass57_174 == null) aClass57_181 = null; break; } try { this.wait(); } catch (InterruptedException interruptedexception) { /* empty */ } } } try { int i = class57.anInt1348; if ((i ^ 0xffffffff) == -2) class57.anObject1351 = new Socket(anInetAddress178, class57.anInt1350); else if (i != 2) { if (i != 4) { if ((i ^ 0xffffffff) == -10) { Object[] objects = (Object[]) class57.anObject1353; class57.anObject1351 = (((Class) objects[0]).getDeclaredMethod ((String) objects[1], (Class[]) objects[2])); } else if (i == 10) { Object[] objects = (Object[]) class57.anObject1353; class57.anObject1351 = ((Class) objects[0]) .getDeclaredField((String) objects[1]); } else throw new Exception(); } else class57.anObject1351 = new DataInputStream(((URL) class57.anObject1353) .openStream()); } else { Thread thread = new Thread((Runnable) class57.anObject1353); thread.setDaemon(true); thread.start(); thread.setPriority(class57.anInt1350); class57.anObject1351 = thread; } class57.anInt1349 = 1; } catch (Exception exception) { class57.anInt1349 = 2; } } }

I believe this is the update server. I will try to decipher where it gets the update url from and then make it return null or something or skip it.

I also figured out this is the file where it downloads the cache, so I’m pretty sure this is it. I’m making a search going from variable to variable to try and find it.

Read full topic

item.title: Bypassing Update Server
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Well, theres only 2 places where it makes a socket, when you log in, and when it connects to the upate server. So if you could find those, the socket created for attaching to the update server is usually closed about ~6 lines down from where it was created

Read full topic
